text:
Ms. Keusch's class decides to make rectangles for each of the whole numbers 1-30.

Drawing Instructions

  • Your teacher will assign your group some numbers between 1 and 30.
  • On the grid paper, draw all the rectangles whose area represents your assigned numbers.
  • On a large sheet of paper, attach and label the grid paper rectangles.
  • List all the factors from least to greatest at the bottom.

Example for the number 15:
Create your posters to display with the rest of the class.

Example of how the larger papers might look:

Note: One teacher used one color of poster paper for odd numbers and a different color of poster paper for even numbers. The red posters contained odd numbers and the yellow posters contained the even numbers. Some interesting patterns seemed more obvious. For example, the prime numbers were all on red posters except for 2. Odd numbers appear to have less factors.

Looking for Patterns

  • Look over the set of rectangles for numbers 1-30 that your class generated. What patterns do you notice?

Student responses will vary. In general, the side lengths of the rectangles will be factors of the number that represents the area of the rectangle. Because these are visual models of the numbers in the chart from Problem 1.1, students may notice a lot of the same patterns but in rectangle form:

  • One poster only has 1 rectangle.
  • Some posters have exactly 2 rectangles (prime numbers).
  • Some posters have lots of rectangles (more than two factors: composite numbers).
  • Some posters g=have a 2 x N, and those are even numbers.
• Maria claims that the rectangles can also represent the relationship between the factors and multiples of numbers. Does this make sense? Explain.
